tags.label: ion-action-sheet-controller
tags.description: Action Sheet controllers programmatically control the action sheet component. Action Sheets can be created and dismissed from the action sheet controller. View the [Action Sheet](../action-sheet) documentation for a full list of options to pass upon creation.

tags.label: ion-action-sheet
tags.description: An Action Sheet is a dialog that displays a set of options. It appears on top of the app's content, and must be manually dismissed by the user before they can resume interaction with the app. Destructive options are made obvious in `ios` mode. There are multiple ways to dismiss the action sheet, including tapping the backdrop or hitting the escape key on desktop.

attributes.label: animated
attributes.description: If `true`, the action sheet will animate.

attributes.label: backdrop-dismiss
attributes.description: If `true`, the action sheet will be dismissed when the backdrop is clicked.

attributes.label: css-class
attributes.description:
Additional classes to apply for custom CSS. If multiple classes are
provided they should be separated by spaces.

attributes.label: header
attributes.description: Title for the action sheet.

attributes.label: keyboard-close
attributes.description: If `true`, the keyboard will be automatically dismissed when the overlay is presented.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: sub-header
attributes.description: Subtitle for the action sheet.

attributes.label: translucent
attributes.description: If `true`, the action sheet will be translucent. Only applies when the mode is `"ios"` and the device supports backdrop-filter.

tags.label: ion-alert-controller
ion-alert
tags.description: An Alert is a dialog that presents users with information or collects information from the user using inputs. An alert appears on top of the app's content, and must be manually dismissed by the user before they can resume interaction with the app. It can also optionally have a `header`, `subHeader` and `message`.

attributes.label: animated
attributes.description: If `true`, the alert will animate.

attributes.label: backdrop-dismiss
attributes.description: If `true`, the alert will be dismissed when the backdrop is clicked.

attributes.label: css-class
attributes.description:
Additional classes to apply for custom CSS. If multiple classes are
provided they should be separated by spaces.

attributes.label: header
attributes.description: The main title in the heading of the alert.

attributes.label: keyboard-close
attributes.description: If `true`, the keyboard will be automatically dismissed when the overlay is presented.

attributes.label: message
attributes.description:
The main message to be displayed in the alert.
`message` can accept either plaintext or HTML as a string.
To display characters normally reserved for HTML, they
must be escaped. For example `<Ionic>` would become
`<Ionic>`

For more information: [Security Documentation](https://ionicframework.com/docs/faq/security)

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: sub-header
attributes.description: The subtitle in the heading of the alert. Displayed under the title.

attributes.label: translucent
attributes.description: If `true`, the alert will be translucent.

tags.label: ion-anchor
tags.description: The Anchor component is used for navigating to a specified link. Similar to the browser's anchor tag, it can accept a href for the location, and a direction for the transition animation.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: href
attributes.description:
Contains a URL or a URL fragment that the hyperlink points to.
If this property is set, an anchor tag will be rendered.

attributes.label: router-direction
attributes.description:
When using a router, it specifies the transition direction when navigating to
another page using `href`.

tags.label: ion-app
tags.description: App is a container element for an Ionic application. There should only be one `<ion-app>` element per project. An app can have many Ionic components including menus, headers, content, and footers. The overlay components get appended to the `<ion-app>` when they are presented.

tags.label: ion-avatar
tags.description:
Avatars are circular components that usually wrap an image or icon. They can be used to represent a person or an object.

Avatars can be used by themselves or inside of any element. If placed inside of an `ion-chip` or `ion-item`, the avatar will resize to fit the parent component. To position an avatar on the left or right side of an item, set the slot to `start` or `end`, respectively.

tags.label: ion-back-button
tags.description:
The back button navigates back in the app's history upon click. It is smart enough to know what to render based on the mode and when to show based on the navigation stack.

To change what is displayed in the back button, use the `text` and `icon` properties.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: default-href
attributes.description: The url to navigate back to by default when there is no history.

attributes.label: icon
attributes.description: The icon name to use for the back button.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: text
attributes.description: The text to display in the back button.

tags.label: ion-backdrop
tags.description: Backdrops are full screen components that overlay other components. They are useful behind components that transition in on top of other content and can be used to dismiss that component.

attributes.label: stop-propagation
attributes.description: If `true`, the backdrop will stop propagation on tap.

attributes.label: tappable
attributes.description: If `true`, the backdrop will can be clicked and will emit the `ionBackdropTap` event.

attributes.label: visible
attributes.description: If `true`, the backdrop will be visible.

tags.label: ion-badge
tags.description: Badges are inline block elements that usually appear near another element. Typically they contain a number or other characters. They can be used as a notification that there are additional items associated with an element and indicate how many items there are.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

tags.label: ion-button
tags.description: Buttons provide a clickable element, which can be used in forms, or anywhere that needs simple, standard button functionality. They may display text, icons, or both. Buttons can be styled with several attributes to look a specific way.

attributes.label: button-type
attributes.description: The type of button.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the button.

attributes.label: expand
attributes.description:
Set to `"block"` for a full-width button or to `"full"` for a full-width button
without left and right borders.

attributes.label: fill
attributes.description:
Set to `"clear"` for a transparent button, to `"outline"` for a transparent
button with a border, or to `"solid"`. The default style is `"solid"` except inside of
a toolbar, where the default is `"clear"`.

attributes.label: href
attributes.description:
Contains a URL or a URL fragment that the hyperlink points to.
If this property is set, an anchor tag will be rendered.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: router-direction
attributes.description:
When using a router, it specifies the transition direction when navigating to
another page using `href`.

attributes.label: shape
attributes.description: The button shape.

attributes.label: size
attributes.description: The button size.

attributes.label: strong
attributes.description: If `true`, activates a button with a heavier font weight.

attributes.label: type
attributes.description: The type of the button.

tags.label: ion-buttons
tags.description:
The Buttons component is a container element. Buttons placed in a toolbar should be placed inside of the `<ion-buttons>` element.

The `<ion-buttons>` element can be positioned inside of the toolbar using a named slot. The below chart has a description of each slot.

| Slot         | Description                                                                                              |
|--------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| `secondary`  | Positions element to the `left` of the content in `ios` mode, and directly to the `right` in `md` mode.  |
| `primary`    | Positions element to the `right` of the content in `ios` mode, and to the far `right` in `md` mode.      |
| `start`      | Positions to the `left` of the content in LTR, and to the `right` in RTL.                                |
| `end`        | Positions to the `right` of the content in LTR, and to the `left` in RTL.                                |

tags.label: ion-card-content
tags.description:
`ion-card-content` is child component of `ion-card` that adds some content padding.
It is recommended that any text content for a card should be placed in an `ion-card-content`.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

tags.label: ion-card-header
tags.description: `ion-card-header` is a header component for `ion-card`.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: translucent
attributes.description: If `true`, the card header will be translucent.

tags.label: ion-card-subtitle
tags.description: `ion-card-subtitle` is a child component of `ion-card`

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

tags.label: ion-card-title
tags.description: `ion-card-title` is a child component of `ion-card`

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

tags.label: ion-card
tags.description:
Cards are a standard piece of UI that serves as an entry point to more detailed
information. A card can be a single component, but is often made up of some
header, title, subtitle, and content. `ion-card` is broken up into several
sub-components to reflect this. Please see `ion-card-content`,
`ion-card-header`, `ion-card-title`, `ion-card-subtitle`.

attributes.label: button
attributes.description: If `true`, a button tag will be rendered and the card will be tappable.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the card.

attributes.label: href
attributes.description:
Contains a URL or a URL fragment that the hyperlink points to.
If this property is set, an anchor tag will be rendered.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: router-direction
attributes.description:
When using a router, it specifies the transition direction when navigating to
another page using `href`.

attributes.label: type
attributes.description: The type of the button. Only used when an `onclick` or `button` property is present.

tags.label: ion-checkbox
tags.description: Checkboxes allow the selection of multiple options from a set of options. They appear as checked (ticked) when activated. Clicking on a checkbox will toggle the `checked` property. They can also be checked programmatically by setting the `checked` property.

attributes.label: checked
attributes.description: If `true`, the checkbox is selected.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the checkbox.

attributes.label: indeterminate
attributes.description: If `true`, the checkbox will visually appear as indeterminate.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: name
attributes.description: The name of the control, which is submitted with the form data.

attributes.label: value
attributes.description:
The value of the toggle does not mean if it's checked or not, use the `checked`
property for that.

The value of a toggle is analogous to the value of a `<input type="checkbox">`,
it's only used when the toggle participates in a native `<form>`.

tags.label: ion-chip
tags.description: Chips represent complex entities in small blocks, such as a contact. A chip can contain several different elements such as avatars, text, and icons.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: outline
attributes.description: Display an outline style button.

tags.label: ion-col
tags.description:
Columns are cellular components of the [grid](../grid) system and go inside of a [row](../row).
They will expand to fill their row. All content within a grid should go inside of a column.

See [Grid Layout](/docs/layout/grid) for more information.

attributes.label: offset
attributes.description:
The amount to offset the column, in terms of how many columns it should shift to the end
of the total available.

attributes.label: offset-lg
attributes.description:
The amount to offset the column for lg screens, in terms of how many columns it should shift
to the end of the total available.

attributes.label: offset-md
attributes.description:
The amount to offset the column for md screens, in terms of how many columns it should shift
to the end of the total available.

attributes.label: offset-sm
attributes.description:
The amount to offset the column for sm screens, in terms of how many columns it should shift
to the end of the total available.

attributes.label: offset-xl
attributes.description:
The amount to offset the column for xl screens, in terms of how many columns it should shift
to the end of the total available.

attributes.label: offset-xs
attributes.description:
The amount to offset the column for xs screens, in terms of how many columns it should shift
to the end of the total available.

attributes.label: pull
attributes.description:
The amount to pull the column, in terms of how many columns it should shift to the start of
the total available.

attributes.label: pull-lg
attributes.description:
The amount to pull the column for lg screens, in terms of how many columns it should shift
to the start of the total available.

attributes.label: pull-md
attributes.description:
The amount to pull the column for md screens, in terms of how many columns it should shift
to the start of the total available.

attributes.label: pull-sm

The amount to pull the column for sm screens, in terms of how many columns it should shift

attributes.label: push-lg

The amount to push the column for lg screens, in terms of how many columns it should shift

attributes.label: push-md

The amount to push the column for md screens, in terms of how many columns it should shift

attributes.label: push-sm

The amount to push the column for sm screens, in terms of how many columns it should shift

tags.label: ion-content
tags.description:
Content component provides an easy to use content area with some useful methods
to control the scrollable area. There should only be one content in a single
view component.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: force-overscroll
attributes.description:
If `true` and the content does not cause an overflow scroll, the scroll interaction will cause a bounce.
If the content exceeds the bounds of ionContent, nothing will change.
Note, the does not disable the system bounce on iOS. That is an OS level setting.

attributes.label: fullscreen
attributes.description:
If `true`, the content will scroll behind the headers
and footers. This effect can easily be seen by setting the toolbar
to transparent.

attributes.label: scroll-events
attributes.description:
Because of performance reasons, ionScroll events are disabled by default, in order to enable them
and start listening from (ionScroll), set this property to `true`.

attributes.label: scroll-x
attributes.description: If you want to enable the content scrolling in the X axis, set this property to `true`.

attributes.label: scroll-y
attributes.description: If you want to disable the content scrolling in the Y axis, set this property to `false`.

tags.label: ion-datetime
tags.description:
Datetimes present a picker interface from the bottom of a page, making it easy for users to select
dates and times. The picker displays scrollable columns that can be used to individually select years,
months, days, hours and minute values. Datetimes are similar to the native `input` elements of type
`datetime-local`, however, Ionic's Datetime component makes it easy to display the date and time in a
preferred format, and manage the datetime values.

attributes.label: cancel-text
attributes.description: The text to display on the picker's cancel button.

attributes.label: day-names
attributes.description:
Full day of the week names. This can be used to provide
locale names for each day in the week. Defaults to English.

attributes.label: day-short-names
attributes.description:
Short abbreviated day of the week names. This can be used to provide
locale names for each day in the week. Defaults to English.

attributes.label: day-values
attributes.description:
Values used to create the list of selectable days. By default
every day is shown for the given month. However, to control exactly which days of
the month to display, the `dayValues` input can take a number, an array of numbers, or
a string of comma separated numbers. Note that even if the array days have an invalid
number for the selected month, like `31` in February, it will correctly not show
days which are not valid for the selected month.

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the datetime.

attributes.label: display-format
attributes.description:
The display format of the date and time as text that shows
within the item. When the `pickerFormat` input is not used, then the
`displayFormat` is used for both display the formatted text, and determining
the datetime picker's columns. See the `pickerFormat` input description for
more info. Defaults to `MMM D, YYYY`.

attributes.label: done-text
attributes.description: The text to display on the picker's "Done" button.

attributes.label: hour-values
attributes.description:
Values used to create the list of selectable hours. By default
the hour values range from `0` to `23` for 24-hour, or `1` to `12` for 12-hour. However,
to control exactly which hours to display, the `hourValues` input can take a number, an
array of numbers, or a string of comma separated numbers.

attributes.label: max
attributes.description:
The maximum datetime allowed. Value must be a date string
following the
[ISO 8601 datetime format standard](https://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime),
`1996-12-19`. The format does not have to be specific to an exact
datetime. For example, the maximum could just be the year, such as `1994`.
Defaults to the end of this year.

attributes.label: min
attributes.description:
The minimum datetime allowed. Value must be a date string
following the
[ISO 8601 datetime format standard](https://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime),
such as `1996-12-19`. The format does not have to be specific to an exact
datetime. For example, the minimum could just be the year, such as `1994`.
Defaults to the beginning of the year, 100 years ago from today.

attributes.label: minute-values
attributes.description:
Values used to create the list of selectable minutes. By default
the minutes range from `0` to `59`. However, to control exactly which minutes to display,
the `minuteValues` input can take a number, an array of numbers, or a string of comma
separated numbers. For example, if the minute selections should only be every 15 minutes,
then this input value would be `minuteValues="0,15,30,45"`.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: month-names
attributes.description:
Full names for each month name. This can be used to provide
locale month names. Defaults to English.

attributes.label: month-short-names
attributes.description:
Short abbreviated names for each month name. This can be used to provide
locale month names. Defaults to English.

attributes.label: month-values
attributes.description:
Values used to create the list of selectable months. By default
the month values range from `1` to `12`. However, to control exactly which months to
display, the `monthValues` input can take a number, an array of numbers, or a string of
comma separated numbers. For example, if only summer months should be shown, then this
input value would be `monthValues="6,7,8"`. Note that month numbers do *not* have a
zero-based index, meaning January's value is `1`, and December's is `12`.

attributes.label: name
attributes.description: The name of the control, which is submitted with the form data.

attributes.label: picker-format
attributes.description:
The format of the date and time picker columns the user selects.
A datetime input can have one or many datetime parts, each getting their
own column which allow individual selection of that particular datetime part. For
example, year and month columns are two individually selectable columns which help
choose an exact date from the datetime picker. Each column follows the string
parse format. Defaults to use `displayFormat`.

attributes.label: placeholder
attributes.description:
The text to display when there's no date selected yet.
Using lowercase to match the input attribute

attributes.label: readonly
attributes.description: If `true`, the datetime appears normal but is not interactive.

attributes.label: value
attributes.description: The value of the datetime as a valid ISO 8601 datetime string.

attributes.label: year-values
attributes.description:
Values used to create the list of selectable years. By default
the year values range between the `min` and `max` datetime inputs. However, to
control exactly which years to display, the `yearValues` input can take a number, an array
of numbers, or string of comma separated numbers. For example, to show upcoming and
recent leap years, then this input's value would be `yearValues="2024,2020,2016,2012,2008"`.

tags.label: ion-fab-button
tags.description:
Floating Action Buttons (FABs) represent the primary action in an application. By default, they have a circular shape. When pressed, the button may open more related actions. As the name suggests, FABs generally float over the content in a fixed position. This is not achieved exclusively by using an `<ion-fab-button>FAB</ion-fab-button>`. They need to be wrapped with an `<ion-fab>` component in order to be fixed over the content.

If the FAB button is not wrapped with `<ion-fab>`, it will scroll with the content. FAB buttons have a default size, a mini size and can accept different colors:

attributes.label: activated
attributes.description: If `true`, the fab button will be show a close icon.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the fab button.

attributes.label: href
attributes.description:
Contains a URL or a URL fragment that the hyperlink points to.
If this property is set, an anchor tag will be rendered.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: router-direction
attributes.description:
When using a router, it specifies the transition direction when navigating to
another page using `href`.

attributes.label: show
attributes.description: If `true`, the fab button will show when in a fab-list.

attributes.label: size
attributes.description: The size of the button. Set this to `small` in order to have a mini fab.

attributes.label: translucent
attributes.description: If `true`, the fab button will be translucent.

attributes.label: type
attributes.description: The type of the button.

tags.label: ion-fab-list
tags.description: The `ion-fab-list` element is a container for multiple fab buttons. This collection of fab buttons contains actions related to the main fab button and is flung out on click. To specify what side the buttons should appear on, set the `side` property to 'start', 'end', 'top', 'bottom'

attributes.label: activated
attributes.description: If `true`, the fab list will show all fab buttons in the list.

attributes.label: side
attributes.description: The side the fab list will show on relative to the main fab button.

tags.label: ion-fab
tags.description: Fabs are container elements that contain one or more fab buttons. They should be placed in a fixed position that does not scroll with the content. Fab should have one main fab-button. Fabs can also contain fab-lists which contain related buttons that show when the main fab button is clicked. The same fab container can contain several [fab-list](../fab-list) elements with different side values.

attributes.label: activated
attributes.description:
If `true`, both the `ion-fab-button` and all `ion-fab-list` inside `ion-fab` will become active.
That means `ion-fab-button` will become a `close` icon and `ion-fab-list` will become visible.

attributes.label: edge
attributes.description:
If `true`, the fab will display on the edge of the header if
`vertical` is `"top"`, and on the edge of the footer if
it is `"bottom"`. Should be used with a `fixed` slot.

attributes.label: horizontal
attributes.description: Where to align the fab horizontally in the viewport.

attributes.label: vertical
attributes.description: Where to align the fab vertically in the viewport.

tags.label: ion-footer
tags.description:
Footer is a root component of a page that sits at the bottom of the page.
Footer can be a wrapper for ion-toolbar to make sure the content area is sized correctly.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: translucent
attributes.description:
If `true`, the footer will be translucent.
Note: In order to scroll content behind the footer, the `fullscreen`
attribute needs to be set on the content.

tags.label: ion-grid
tags.description:
The grid is a powerful mobile-first flexbox system for building custom layouts.

It is composed of three units — a grid, [row(s)](../row) and [column(s)](../col). Columns will expand to fill the row, and will resize to fit additional columns. It is based on a 12 column layout with different breakpoints based on the screen size. The number of columns can be customized using CSS.

See [Grid Layout](/docs/layout/grid) for more information.

attributes.label: fixed
attributes.description: If `true`, the grid will have a fixed width based on the screen size.

tags.label: ion-header
tags.description:
Header is a parent component that holds the toolbar component.
It's important to note that ion-header needs to be the one of the three root elements of a page

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: translucent
attributes.description:
If `true`, the header will be translucent.
Note: In order to scroll content behind the header, the `fullscreen`
attribute needs to be set on the content.

tags.label: ion-img
tags.description: Img is a tag that will lazily load an image when ever the tag is in the viewport. This is extremely useful when generating a large list as images are only loaded when they're visible. The component uses [Intersection Observer](https://caniuse.com/#feat=intersectionobserver) internally, which is supported in most modern browser, but falls back to a `setTimeout` when it is not supported.

attributes.label: alt
attributes.description:
This attribute defines the alternative text describing the image.
Users will see this text displayed if the image URL is wrong,
the image is not in one of the supported formats, or if the image is not yet downloaded.

attributes.label: src
attributes.description: The image URL. This attribute is mandatory for the element.

tags.label: ion-infinite-scroll-content
tags.description: The `ion-infinite-scroll-content` component is the default child used by the `ion-infinite-scroll`. It displays an infinite scroll spinner that looks best based on the platform and changes the look depending on the infinite scroll's state. The default spinner can be changed and text can be added by setting the `loadingSpinner` and `loadingText` properties.

attributes.label: loading-spinner
attributes.description: An animated SVG spinner that shows while loading.

attributes.label: loading-text
attributes.description:
Optional text to display while loading.
`loadingText` can accept either plaintext or HTML as a string.
To display characters normally reserved for HTML, they
must be escaped. For example `<Ionic>` would become
`<Ionic>`

For more information: [Security Documentation](https://ionicframework.com/docs/faq/security)

tags.label: ion-infinite-scroll
tags.description:
The Infinite Scroll component calls an action to be performed when the user scrolls a specified distance from the bottom or top of the page.

The expression assigned to the `ionInfinite` event is called when the user reaches that defined distance. When this expression has finished any and all tasks, it should call the `complete()` method on the infinite scroll instance.

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description:
If `true`, the infinite scroll will be hidden and scroll event listeners
will be removed.

Set this to true to disable the infinite scroll from actively
trying to receive new data while scrolling. This is useful
when it is known that there is no more data that can be added, and
the infinite scroll is no longer needed.

attributes.label: position
attributes.description:
The position of the infinite scroll element.
The value can be either `top` or `bottom`.

attributes.label: threshold
attributes.description:
The threshold distance from the bottom
of the content to call the `infinite` output event when scrolled.
The threshold value can be either a percent, or
in pixels. For example, use the value of `10%` for the `infinite`
output event to get called when the user has scrolled 10%
from the bottom of the page. Use the value `100px` when the
scroll is within 100 pixels from the bottom of the page.

tags.label: ion-input
tags.description:
The input component is a wrapper to the HTML input element with custom styling and additional functionality. It accepts most of the same properties as the HTML input, but works great on desktop devices and integrates with the keyboard on mobile devices.

It is meant for text `type` inputs only, such as `"text"`, `"password"`, `"email"`, `"number"`, `"search"`, `"tel"`, and `"url"`. It supports all standard text input events including keyup, keydown, keypress, and more.

attributes.label: accept
attributes.description: If the value of the type attribute is `"file"`, then this attribute will indicate the types of files that the server accepts, otherwise it will be ignored. The value must be a comma-separated list of unique content type specifiers.

attributes.label: autocapitalize
attributes.description: Indicates whether and how the text value should be automatically capitalized as it is entered/edited by the user.

attributes.label: autocomplete
attributes.description: Indicates whether the value of the control can be automatically completed by the browser.

attributes.label: autocorrect
attributes.description: Whether auto correction should be enabled when the user is entering/editing the text value.

attributes.label: autofocus
attributes.description: This Boolean attribute lets you specify that a form control should have input focus when the page loads.

attributes.label: clear-input
attributes.description: If `true`, a clear icon will appear in the input when there is a value. Clicking it clears the input.

attributes.label: clear-on-edit
attributes.description: If `true`, the value will be cleared after focus upon edit. Defaults to `true` when `type` is `"password"`, `false` for all other types.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: debounce
attributes.description: Set the amount of time, in milliseconds, to wait to trigger the `ionChange` event after each keystroke.

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the input.

attributes.label: inputmode
attributes.description:
A hint to the browser for which keyboard to display.
This attribute applies when the value of the type attribute is `"text"`, `"password"`, `"email"`, or `"url"`. Possible values are: `"verbatim"`, `"latin"`, `"latin-name"`, `"latin-prose"`, `"full-width-latin"`, `"kana"`, `"katakana"`, `"numeric"`, `"tel"`, `"email"`, `"url"`.

attributes.label: max
attributes.description: The maximum value, which must not be less than its minimum (min attribute) value.

attributes.label: maxlength
attributes.description: If the value of the type attribute is `text`, `email`, `search`, `password`, `tel`, or `url`, this attribute specifies the maximum number of characters that the user can enter.

attributes.label: min
attributes.description: The minimum value, which must not be greater than its maximum (max attribute) value.

attributes.label: minlength
attributes.description: If the value of the type attribute is `text`, `email`, `search`, `password`, `tel`, or `url`, this attribute specifies the minimum number of characters that the user can enter.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: multiple
attributes.description: If `true`, the user can enter more than one value. This attribute applies when the type attribute is set to `"email"` or `"file"`, otherwise it is ignored.

attributes.label: name
attributes.description: The name of the control, which is submitted with the form data.

attributes.label: pattern
attributes.description: A regular expression that the value is checked against. The pattern must match the entire value, not just some subset. Use the title attribute to describe the pattern to help the user. This attribute applies when the value of the type attribute is `"text"`, `"search"`, `"tel"`, `"url"`, `"email"`, or `"password"`, otherwise it is ignored.

attributes.label: placeholder
attributes.description: Instructional text that shows before the input has a value.

attributes.label: readonly
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot modify the value.

attributes.label: required
attributes.description: If `true`, the user must fill in a value before submitting a form.

attributes.label: size
attributes.description: The initial size of the control. This value is in pixels unless the value of the type attribute is `"text"` or `"password"`, in which case it is an integer number of characters. This attribute applies only when the `type` attribute is set to `"text"`, `"search"`, `"tel"`, `"url"`, `"email"`, or `"password"`, otherwise it is ignored.

attributes.label: spellcheck
attributes.description: If `true`, the element will have its spelling and grammar checked.

attributes.label: step
attributes.description:
Works with the min and max attributes to limit the increments at which a value can be set.
Possible values are: `"any"` or a positive floating point number.

attributes.label: type
attributes.description: The type of control to display. The default type is text.

attributes.label: value
attributes.description: The value of the input.

tags.label: ion-item-divider
tags.description: Item Dividers are block elements that can be used to separate items in a list. They are similar to list headers, but instead of being placed at the top of a list, they should go in between groups of like items.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: sticky
attributes.description:
When it's set to `true`, the item-divider will stay visible when it reaches the top
of the viewport until the next `ion-item-divider` replaces it.

This feature relies in `position:sticky`:
https://caniuse.com/#feat=css-sticky

tags.label: ion-item-group
tags.description: Item groups are containers that organize similar items together. They can contain item dividers to divide the items into multiple sections.

tags.label: ion-item-option
tags.description:
The option button for an `ion-item-sliding`. Must be placed inside of an `<ion-item-options>`.
You can combine the `ionSwipe` event and the `expandable` directive to create a full swipe
action for the item.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the item option.

attributes.label: expandable
attributes.description: If `true`, the option will expand to take up the available width and cover any other options.

attributes.label: href
attributes.description:
Contains a URL or a URL fragment that the hyperlink points to.
If this property is set, an anchor tag will be rendered.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

tags.label: ion-item-options
tags.description:
The option buttons for an `ion-item-sliding`. These buttons can be placed either on the [start or end side](#side-description).
You can combine the `ionSwipe` event plus the `expandable` directive to create a full swipe action for the item.

attributes.label: side
attributes.description: The side the option button should be on. Possible values: `"start"` and `"end"`. If you have multiple `ion-item-options`, a side must be provided for each.

tags.label: ion-item-sliding
tags.description: A sliding item contains an item that can be dragged to reveal buttons. It requires an [item](../item) component as a child. All options to reveal should be placed in the [item options](../item-options) element.

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the sliding-item.

tags.label: ion-item
tags.description: Items are elements that can contain text, icons, avatars, images, inputs, and any other native or custom elements. Generally they are placed in a list with other items. Items can be swiped, deleted, reordered, edited, and more.

attributes.label: button
attributes.description: If `true`, a button tag will be rendered and the item will be tappable.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: detail
attributes.description:
If `true`, a detail arrow will appear on the item. Defaults to `false` unless the `mode`
is `ios` and an `href` or `button` property is present.

attributes.label: detail-icon
attributes.description: The icon to use when `detail` is set to `true`.

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the item.

attributes.label: href
attributes.description:
Contains a URL or a URL fragment that the hyperlink points to.
If this property is set, an anchor tag will be rendered.

attributes.label: lines
attributes.description: How the bottom border should be displayed on the item.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: router-direction
attributes.description:
When using a router, it specifies the transition direction when navigating to
another page using `href`.

attributes.label: type
attributes.description: The type of the button. Only used when an `onclick` or `button` property is present.

tags.label: ion-label
tags.description: Label is a wrapper element that can be used in combination with `ion-item`, `ion-input`, `ion-toggle`, and more. The position of the label inside of an item can be inline, fixed, stacked, or floating.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: position
attributes.description: The position determines where and how the label behaves inside an item.

tags.label: ion-list-header
tags.description:
ListHeader a header component for a list.
Unlike ItemDivider, ListHeaders are styled to be stand-out from the rest of the list items.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

tags.label: ion-list
tags.description:
Lists are made up of multiple rows of items which can contain text, buttons, toggles,
icons, thumbnails, and much more. Lists generally contain items with similar data content, such as images and text.

Lists support several interactions including swiping items to reveal options, dragging to reorder items within the list, and deleting items.

attributes.label: inset
attributes.description: If `true`, the list will have margin around it and rounded corners.

attributes.label: lines
attributes.description: How the bottom border should be displayed on all items.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

tags.label: ion-loading-controller
tags.description: Loading controllers programmatically control the loading component. Loadings can be created and dismissed from the loading controller. View the [Loading](../loading) documentation for a full list of options to pass upon creation.

tags.label: ion-loading
tags.description: An overlay that can be used to indicate activity while blocking user interaction. The loading indicator appears on top of the app's content, and can be dismissed by the app to resume user interaction with the app. It includes an optional backdrop, which can be disabled by setting `showBackdrop: false` upon creation.

attributes.label: animated
attributes.description: If `true`, the loading indicator will animate.

attributes.label: backdrop-dismiss
attributes.description: If `true`, the loading indicator will be dismissed when the backdrop is clicked.

attributes.label: css-class
attributes.description:
Additional classes to apply for custom CSS. If multiple classes are
provided they should be separated by spaces.

attributes.label: duration
attributes.description: Number of milliseconds to wait before dismissing the loading indicator.

attributes.label: keyboard-close
attributes.description: If `true`, the keyboard will be automatically dismissed when the overlay is presented.

attributes.label: message
attributes.description: Optional text content to display in the loading indicator.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: show-backdrop
attributes.description: If `true`, a backdrop will be displayed behind the loading indicator.

attributes.label: spinner
attributes.description: The name of the spinner to display.

attributes.label: translucent
attributes.description: If `true`, the loading indicator will be translucent.

tags.label: ion-menu-button
tags.description: Menu Button is component that automatically creates the icon and functionality to open a menu on a page.

attributes.label: auto-hide
attributes.description: Automatically hides the menu button when the corresponding menu is not active

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: menu
attributes.description: Optional property that maps to a Menu's `menuId` prop. Can also be `start` or `end` for the menu side. This is used to find the correct menu to toggle

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

tags.label: ion-menu-controller
tags.description: The Menu Controller makes it easy to control a Menu. The methods provided can be used to display the menu, enable the menu, toggle the menu, and more. The controller will grab a reference to the menu by the side, or id. if neither of these are passed to it, it will grab the first menu it finds.

tags.label: ion-menu-toggle
tags.description:
The MenuToggle component can be used to toggle a menu open or closed.

By default, it's only visible when the selected menu is active. A menu is active when it can be opened/closed. If the menu is disabled or it's being presented as a split-pane, the menu is marked as non-active and ion-menu-toggle hides itself.

In case it's desired to keep `ion-menu-toggle` always visible, the `autoHide` property can be set to `false`.

attributes.label: auto-hide
attributes.description:
Automatically hides the content when the corresponding menu is not active.

By default, it's `true`. Change it to `false` in order to
keep `ion-menu-toggle` always visible regardless the state of the menu.

attributes.label: menu
attributes.description:
Optional property that maps to a Menu's `menuId` prop.
Can also be `start` or `end` for the menu side.
This is used to find the correct menu to toggle.

If this property is not used, `ion-menu-toggle` will toggle the
first menu that is active.

tags.label: ion-menu
tags.description:
The Menu component is a navigation drawer that slides in from the side of the current view.
By default, it slides in from the left, but the side can be overridden.
The menu will be displayed differently based on the mode, however the display type can be changed to any of the available menu types.
The menu element should be a sibling to the root content element.
There can be any number of menus attached to the content.
These can be controlled from the templates, or programmatically using the MenuController.

attributes.label: content-id
attributes.description: The content's id the menu should use.

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the menu is disabled.

attributes.label: max-edge-start
attributes.description:
The edge threshold for dragging the menu open.
If a drag/swipe happens over this value, the menu is not triggered.

attributes.label: menu-id
attributes.description: An id for the menu.

attributes.label: side
attributes.description: Which side of the view the menu should be placed.

attributes.label: swipe-gesture
attributes.description: If `true`, swiping the menu is enabled.

attributes.label: type
attributes.description:
The animation type of the menu.
Available options: `"overlay"`, `"reveal"`, `"push"`.
Custom animations can be registered by the menu controller.

tags.label: ion-modal-controller
tags.description: Modal controllers programmatically control the modal component. Modals can be created and dismissed from the modal controller. View the [Modal](../modal) documentation for a full list of options to pass upon creation.

tags.label: ion-modal
tags.description: A Modal is a dialog that appears on top of the app's content, and must be dismissed by the app before interaction can resume. It is useful as a select component when there are a lot of options to choose from, or when filtering items in a list, as well as many other use cases.

attributes.label: animated
attributes.description: If `true`, the modal will animate.

attributes.label: backdrop-dismiss
attributes.description: If `true`, the modal will be dismissed when the backdrop is clicked.

attributes.label: component
attributes.description: The component to display inside of the modal.

attributes.label: css-class
attributes.description:
Additional classes to apply for custom CSS. If multiple classes are
provided they should be separated by spaces.

attributes.label: keyboard-close
attributes.description: If `true`, the keyboard will be automatically dismissed when the overlay is presented.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: show-backdrop
attributes.description: If `true`, a backdrop will be displayed behind the modal.

tags.label: ion-nav-pop
tags.description: `NavPop` is a component used the automatically go back in navigation. It is the element from of `NavController.pop()`

tags.label: ion-nav-push
tags.description:
`NavPush` is a component used to navigate to the specified component.
It is the element form of `NavController.push()`

attributes.label: component
attributes.description: Component to navigate to

tags.label: ion-nav-set-root
tags.description:
`NavSetRoot` is an element that allows you to set the root of the current navigation stack.
It is the element form a calling `NavController.setRoot()`

attributes.label: component
attributes.description: Component you want to make root for the navigation stack

tags.label: ion-nav
tags.description:
Nav is a standalone component for loading arbitrary components and pushing to new components on to the stack.
Unlike RouterOutlet, Nav is not tied to a particular router. Meaning that if we load a Nav component, and push other components to the stack, they will not affect the apps overall router. This fits use cases where you could have a modal, which needs it's own sub-navigation, but not make it tied to the apps URL.

attributes.label: animated
attributes.description: If `true`, the nav should animate the transition of components.

attributes.label: root
attributes.description: Root NavComponent to load

attributes.label: swipe-gesture
attributes.description: If the nav component should allow for swipe-to-go-back.

tags.label: ion-note
tags.description: Notes are text elements generally used as subtitles that provide more information. Notes are styled to appear grey by default. Notes can be used in an item as metadata text.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

tags.label: ion-picker
tags.description: A Picker is a dialog that displays a row of buttons and columns underneath. It appears on top of the app's content, and at the bottom of the viewport.

attributes.label: animated
attributes.description: If `true`, the picker will animate.

attributes.label: backdrop-dismiss
attributes.description: If `true`, the picker will be dismissed when the backdrop is clicked.

attributes.label: css-class
attributes.description:
Additional classes to apply for custom CSS. If multiple classes are
provided they should be separated by spaces.

attributes.label: duration
attributes.description: Number of milliseconds to wait before dismissing the picker.

attributes.label: keyboard-close
attributes.description: If `true`, the keyboard will be automatically dismissed when the overlay is presented.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: show-backdrop
attributes.description: If `true`, a backdrop will be displayed behind the picker.

tags.label: ion-popover-controller
tags.description: Popover controllers programmatically control the popover component. Popovers can be created and dismissed from the popover controller. View the [Popover](../popover) documentation for a full list of options to pass upon creation.

tags.label: ion-popover
tags.description: A Popover is a dialog that appears on top of the current page. It can be used for anything, but generally it is used for overflow actions that don't fit in the navigation bar.

attributes.label: animated
attributes.description: If `true`, the popover will animate.

attributes.label: backdrop-dismiss
attributes.description: If `true`, the popover will be dismissed when the backdrop is clicked.

attributes.label: component
attributes.description: The component to display inside of the popover.

attributes.label: css-class
attributes.description:
Additional classes to apply for custom CSS. If multiple classes are
provided they should be separated by spaces.

attributes.label: event
attributes.description: The event to pass to the popover animation.

attributes.label: keyboard-close
attributes.description: If `true`, the keyboard will be automatically dismissed when the overlay is presented.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: show-backdrop
attributes.description: If `true`, a backdrop will be displayed behind the popover.

attributes.label: translucent
attributes.description: If `true`, the popover will be translucent.

tags.label: ion-progress-bar
tags.description: ion-progress-bar is a horizontal progress bar to visualize the progression of an operation and activity. You can choose between two types: `determinate` and `indeterminate`.

attributes.label: buffer
attributes.description:
If the buffer and value are smaller than 1, the buffer circles will show.
The buffer should be between [0, 1].

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: reversed
attributes.description: If true, reverse the progress bar direction.

attributes.label: type
attributes.description:
The state of the progress bar, based on if the time the process takes is known or not.
Default options are: `"determinate"` (no animation), `"indeterminate"` (animate from left to right).

attributes.label: value
attributes.description:
The value determines how much of the active bar should display when the
`type` is `"determinate"`.
The value should be between [0, 1].

tags.label: ion-radio-group
tags.description:
A radio group is a group of [radio buttons](../radio). It allows
a user to select at most one radio button from a set. Checking one radio
button that belongs to a radio group unchecks any previous checked
radio button within the same group.

attributes.label: allow-empty-selection
attributes.description: If `true`, the radios can be deselected.

attributes.label: name
attributes.description: The name of the control, which is submitted with the form data.

attributes.label: value
attributes.description: the value of the radio group.

tags.label: ion-radio
tags.description:
Radios are generally used as a set of related options inside of a group, but they can also be used alone. Pressing on a radio will check it. They can also be checked programmatically by setting the `checked` property.

An `ion-radio-group` can be used to group a set of radios. When radios are inside of a [radio group](../radio-group), only one radio in the group will be checked at any time. Pressing a radio will check it and uncheck the previously selected radio, if there is one. If a radio is not in a group with another radio, then both radios will have the ability to be checked at the same time.

attributes.label: checked
attributes.description: If `true`, the radio is selected.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the radio.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: name
attributes.description: The name of the control, which is submitted with the form data.

attributes.label: value
attributes.description: the value of the radio.

tags.label: ion-range
tags.description:
The Range slider lets users select from a range of values by moving
the slider knob. It can accept dual knobs, but by default one knob
controls the value of the range.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: debounce
attributes.description:
How long, in milliseconds, to wait to trigger the
`ionChange` event after each change in the range value.

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the range.

attributes.label: dual-knobs
attributes.description: Show two knobs.

attributes.label: max
attributes.description: Maximum integer value of the range.

attributes.label: min
attributes.description: Minimum integer value of the range.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: name
attributes.description: The name of the control, which is submitted with the form data.

attributes.label: pin
attributes.description:
If `true`, a pin with integer value is shown when the knob
is pressed.

attributes.label: snaps
attributes.description:
If `true`, the knob snaps to tick marks evenly spaced based
on the step property value.

attributes.label: step
attributes.description: Specifies the value granularity.

attributes.label: ticks
attributes.description:
If `true`, tick marks are displayed based on the step value.
Only applies when `snaps` is `true`.

attributes.label: value
attributes.description: the value of the range.

tags.label: ion-refresher-content
tags.description: The refresher content contains the text, icon and spinner to display during a pull-to-refresh. Ionic provides the pulling icon and refreshing spinner based on the platform. However, the default icon, spinner, and text can be customized based on the state of the refresher.

attributes.label: pulling-icon
attributes.description: A static icon to display when you begin to pull down

attributes.label: pulling-text
attributes.description:
The text you want to display when you begin to pull down.
`pullingText` can accept either plaintext or HTML as a string.
To display characters normally reserved for HTML, they
must be escaped. For example `<Ionic>` would become
`<Ionic>`

For more information: [Security Documentation](https://ionicframework.com/docs/faq/security)

attributes.label: refreshing-spinner
attributes.description: An animated SVG spinner that shows when refreshing begins

attributes.label: refreshing-text
attributes.description:
The text you want to display when performing a refresh.
`refreshingText` can accept either plaintext or HTML as a string.
To display characters normally reserved for HTML, they
must be escaped. For example `<Ionic>` would become
`<Ionic>`

For more information: [Security Documentation](https://ionicframework.com/docs/faq/security)

tags.label: ion-refresher
tags.description:
The refresher provides pull-to-refresh functionality on a content component.
The pull-to-refresh pattern lets a user pull down on a list of data using touch
in order to retrieve more data.

Data should be modified during the refresher's output events. Once the async
operation has completed and the refreshing should end, call `complete()` on the
refresher.

attributes.label: close-duration
attributes.description: Time it takes to close the refresher.

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the refresher will be hidden.

attributes.label: pull-factor
attributes.description:
How much to multiply the pull speed by. To slow the pull animation down,
pass a number less than `1`. To speed up the pull, pass a number greater
than `1`. The default value is `1` which is equal to the speed of the cursor.
If a negative value is passed in, the factor will be `1` instead.

For example: If the value passed is `1.2` and the content is dragged by
`10` pixels, instead of `10` pixels the content will be pulled by `12` pixels
(an increase of 20 percent). If the value passed is `0.8`, the dragged amount
will be `8` pixels, less than the amount the cursor has moved.

attributes.label: pull-max
attributes.description:
The maximum distance of the pull until the refresher
will automatically go into the `refreshing` state.
Defaults to the result of `pullMin + 60`.

attributes.label: pull-min
attributes.description:
The minimum distance the user must pull down until the
refresher will go into the `refreshing` state.

attributes.label: snapback-duration
attributes.description: Time it takes the refresher to to snap back to the `refreshing` state.

tags.label: ion-reorder-group
tags.description:
The reorder group is a wrapper component for items using the `ion-reorder` component. See the [Reorder documentation](../reorder/) for further information about the anchor component that is used to drag items within the `ion-reorder-group`.

Once the user drags an item and drops it in a new position, the `ionItemReorder` event is dispatched. A handler for it should be implemented that calls the `complete()` method.

The `detail` property of the `ionItemReorder` event includes all of the relevant information about the reorder operation, including the `from` and `to` indexes. In the context of reordering, an item moves `from` an index `to` a new index.

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the reorder will be hidden.

tags.label: ion-reorder
tags.description:
Reorder is a component that allows an item in a group of items to be dragged to change its order within that group. It must be used within an `ion-reorder-group` to provide a visual drag and drop interface.

`ion-reorder` is the anchor used to drag and drop the items inside of the `ion-reorder-group`. See the [Reorder Group](../reorder-group) for more information on how to complete the reorder operation.

tags.label: ion-ripple-effect
tags.description: The ripple effect component adds the [Material Design ink ripple interaction effect](https://material.io/develop/web/components/ripples/). This component can be used without a button and can be added to any component.

attributes.label: type
attributes.description:
Sets the type of ripple-effect:

- `bounded`: the ripple effect expands from the user's click position
- `unbounded`: the ripple effect expands from the center of the button and overflows the container.

NOTE: Surfaces for bounded ripples should have the overflow property set to hidden,
while surfaces for unbounded ripples should have it set to visible.

tags.label: ion-route-redirect
tags.description:
A redirect router can only be used in the scope of `ion-router` as a direct children of it.

> Note: this is only meant for vanilla JavaScript project. For Angular projects, use `ion-router-outlet` and the Angular router.

This route has only two configurable values:
 - `from`
 - `to`

Their meaning is obvious under the context of a redirection, that occurs `from` a given URL `to` another given URL.

In other for a redirection to occurs the `from` path needs to be an exact match of the navigated URL.

attributes.label: from
attributes.description:
A redirect route, redirects "from" a URL "to" another URL. This property is that "from" URL.
It needs to be an exact match of the navigated URL in order to apply.

The path specified in this value is always an absolute path, even if the initial `/` slash
is not specified.

attributes.label: to
attributes.description:
A redirect route, redirects "from" a URL "to" another URL. This property is that "to" URL.
When the defined `ion-route-redirect` rule matches, the router will redirect to the path
specified in this property.

The value of this property is always an absolute path inside the scope of routes defined in
`ion-router` it can't be used with another router or to perform a redirection to a different domain.

Note that this is a virtual redirect, it will not cause a real browser refresh, again, it's
a redirect inside the context of ion-router.

When this property is not specified or his value is `undefined` the whole redirect route is noop,
even if the "from" value matches.

tags.label: ion-route
tags.description:
Router is a component that can take a component, and render it when the Browser URl matches the url prop

> Note: this is only meant for vanilla JavaScript project. For Angular projects, use `ion-router-outlet` and the Angular router.

attributes.label: component
attributes.description:
Name of the component to load/select in the navigation outlet (`ion-tabs`, `ion-nav`)
when the route matches.

The value of this property is not always the tagname of the component to load,
in `ion-tabs` it actually refers to the name of the `ion-tab` to select.

attributes.label: url
attributes.description:
Relative path that needs to match in order for this route to apply.

Accepts paths similar to expressjs so that you can define parameters
in the url /foo/:bar where bar would be available in incoming props.

tags.label: ion-router-outlet
tags.description:
Router Outlet is a component used in routing within an Angular app.
Router Outlet behaves in a similar way as Angular's built-in Router Outlet component, but contains the logic for providing a stacked navigation, and animating views in and out.


> Note: this is only meant for Angular projects. For vanilla JavaScript, use `ion-router` and `ion-route` instead.

While Router Outlet has methods for navigating around, it's recommended to use the navigation methods in Angular's router.

attributes.label: animated
attributes.description: If `true`, the router-outlet should animate the transition of components.

tags.label: ion-router
tags.description:
Router is a component for handling routing inside vanilla JavaScript projects. For Angular projects, use `ion-router-outlet` and the Angular router.

Apps should have a single `ion-router` component in the codebase.
This component controls all interactions with the browser history and it aggregates updates through an event system.

`ion-router` is just a URL coordinator for the navigation outlets of ionic: `ion-nav` and `ion-tabs`.

That means the `ion-router` never touches the DOM, it does NOT show the components or emit any kind of lifecycle events, it just tells `ion-nav` and `ion-tabs` what and when to "show" based on the browser's URL.

In order to configure this relationship between components (to load/select) and URLs, `ion-router` uses a declarative syntax using JSX/HTML to define a tree of routes.

If you're using Angular, please see [ion-router-outlet](../router-outlet) instead.

attributes.label: root
attributes.description:
By default `ion-router` will match the routes at the root path ("/").
That can be changed when

attributes.label: use-hash
attributes.description:
The router can work in two "modes":
- With hash: `/index.html#/path/to/page`
- Without hash: `/path/to/page`

Using one or another might depend in the requirements of your app and/or where it's deployed.

Usually "hash-less" navigation works better for SEO and it's more user friendly too, but it might
requires additional server-side configuration in order to properly work.

On the otherside hash-navigation is much easier to deploy, it even works over the file protocol.

By default, this property is `true`, change to `false` to allow hash-less URLs.

tags.label: ion-row
tags.description:
Rows are horizontal components of the [grid](../grid) system and contain varying numbers of
[columns](../col). They ensure the columns are positioned properly.

See [Grid Layout](/docs/layout/grid) for more information.

tags.label: ion-searchbar
tags.description:
Searchbars represent a text field that can be used to search through a collection. They can be displayed inside of a toolbar or the main content.

A Searchbar should be used instead of an input to search lists. A clear button is displayed upon entering input in the searchbar's text field. Clicking on the clear button will erase the text field and the input will remain focused. A cancel button can be enabled which will clear the input and lose the focus upon click.

attributes.label: animated
attributes.description: If `true`, enable searchbar animation.

attributes.label: autocomplete
attributes.description: Set the input's autocomplete property.

attributes.label: autocorrect
attributes.description: Set the input's autocorrect property.

attributes.label: cancel-button-icon
attributes.description: Set the cancel button icon. Only applies to `md` mode.

attributes.label: cancel-button-text
attributes.description: Set the the cancel button text. Only applies to `ios` mode.

attributes.label: clear-icon
attributes.description: Set the clear icon. Defaults to `"close-circle"` for `ios` and `"close"` for `md`.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: debounce
attributes.description: Set the amount of time, in milliseconds, to wait to trigger the `ionChange` event after each keystroke.

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the input.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: placeholder
attributes.description:
Set the input's placeholder.
`placeholder` can accept either plaintext or HTML as a string.
To display characters normally reserved for HTML, they
must be escaped. For example `<Ionic>` would become
`<Ionic>`

For more information: [Security Documentation](https://ionicframework.com/docs/faq/security)

attributes.label: search-icon
attributes.description: The icon to use as the search icon.

attributes.label: show-cancel-button
attributes.description: If `true`, show the cancel button.

attributes.label: spellcheck
attributes.description: If `true`, enable spellcheck on the input.

attributes.label: type
attributes.description: Set the type of the input.

attributes.label: value
attributes.description: the value of the searchbar.

tags.label: ion-segment-button
tags.description: Segment buttons are groups of related buttons inside of a [Segment](../segment). They are displayed in a horizontal row. A segment button can be checked by default by adding the `checked` attribute or by setting the `value` of the segment to the `value` of the segment button. Only one segment button should be selected at a time.

attributes.label: checked
attributes.description: If `true`, the segment button is selected.

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the segment button.

attributes.label: layout
attributes.description: Set the layout of the text and icon in the segment.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: value
attributes.description: The value of the segment button.

tags.label: ion-segment
tags.description:
Segments display a group of related buttons, sometimes known as segmented controls, in a horizontal row. They can be displayed inside of a toolbar or the main content.

Their functionality is similar to tabs, where selecting one will deselect all others. Segments are useful for toggling between different views inside of the content. Tabs should be used instead of a segment when clicking on a control should navigate between pages.

attributes.label: color
attributes.description:
The color to use from your application's color palette.
Default options are: `"primary"`, `"secondary"`, `"tertiary"`, `"success"`, `"warning"`, `"danger"`, `"light"`, `"medium"`, and `"dark"`.
For more information on colors, see [theming](/docs/theming/basics).

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the segment.

attributes.label: mode
attributes.description: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

attributes.label: scrollable
attributes.description: If `true`, the segment buttons will overflow and the user can swipe to see them.

attributes.label: value
attributes.description: the value of the segment.

tags.label: ion-select-option
tags.description: SelectOption is a component that is a child element of Select. For more information, see the [Select docs](../select).

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the select option.

attributes.label: selected
attributes.description: If `true`, the element is selected.

attributes.label: value
attributes.description: The text value of the option.

tags.label: ion-select
tags.description:
Selects are form controls to select an option, or options, from a set of options, similar to a native `<select>` element. When a user taps the select, a dialog appears with all of the options in a large, easy to select list.

A select should be used with child `<ion-select-option>` elements. If the child option is not given a `value` attribute then its text will be used as the value.

If `value` is set on the `<ion-select>`, the selected option will be chosen based on that value. Otherwise, the `selected` attribute can be used on the `<ion-select-option>`.

attributes.label: cancel-text
attributes.description: The text to display on the cancel button.

attributes.label: compare-with
attributes.description: A property name or function used to compare object values

attributes.label: disabled
attributes.description: If `true`, the user cannot interact with the select.

attributes.label: interface
attributes.description: The interface the select should use: `action-sheet`, `popover` or `alert`.

attributes.label: interface-options
attributes.description:
Any additional options that the `alert`, `action-sheet` or `popover` interface
can take. See the [AlertController API docs](../../alert/AlertController/#create), the
[ActionSheetController API docs](../../action-sheet/ActionSheetController/#create) and the
[PopoverController API docs](../../popover/PopoverController/#create) for the
create options for each interface.

attributes.label: mode
